Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Defining the genetic architecture underlying nonrandom mating in Arabidopsis thaliana
Award.AbstractNarration:
Robert J. Swanson
IOS-1020325
RUI: Defining the genetic architecture underlying nonrandom mating in Arabidopsis thaliana

It is well known that flowering plants are not reproductively indiscriminate. The pollen dusted across flower stigmas is a mixture, whose proportions do not often match proportions within progeny. In other words, some pollen have greater mating success, a phenomenon called nonrandom mating. Nonrandom mating has striking evolutionary significance in organisms across kingdoms. The genetics of nonrandom mating in flowering plants, however, is less well understood. This project will exploit tools available for the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana to define the genetic elements that direct nonrandom mating. A fuller understanding of the genetics of plant fertilization is required to facilitate the manipulation of fertilization in agriculture. Finally, the approach proposed in this project requires the training of undergraduates at a primary undergraduate institution; this work will enhance the institution's research and teaching infrastructures, and provide undergraduate students with research training using cutting-edge technology. Such work has great potential to expose and recruit students to research professions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nonrandom mating among compatible mates has long captured the interest of researchers because of its potential significance for processes such as inbreeding depression, sexual selection, reproductive barrier reinforcement, and speciation. Like most sexual organisms, flowering plants mate nonrandomly. Despite nearly 100 years of research, the genetics of how this occurs remains a mystery, and was the goal of this research. The understanding of the genetics of nonrandom mating in plants is significant as it provides new insight into a long-studied, wide-spread evolutionary phenomenon while expanding our understanding of mechanics of plant fertilization, allowing us to potentially manipulate these mechanisms in future crop plants.


We have developed a system in the flowering plant Arabidopsis to easily determine the paternity of progeny from nonrandom mating experiments. Using this system, we have demonstrated that Arabidopsis mates nonrandomly between genetically and geographically distinct populations. Further, we genetically mapped the chromosomal regions responsible for nonrandom mating, and demonstrated that both pollen (male) and pistil (female) genetics play roles in determining who is successful in mating. We used a technique called genome-wide association mapping to allow us to determine the chromosomal regions responsible for this process in more than 200 populations of Arabidopsis. Finally, we developed new microscopy assays that allowed us, for the first time in any plant system, to visualize what happens during pollen competitions that lead to nonrandom mating. In the process of performing these studies, we uncovered fundamental insights into how plants mate. For example, plants that pollinate themselves, such as Arabidopsis (a common reproductive trait in wild and crop plants), show no correlation between the success of mating and the genetic relatedness of the male and female. This is in marked contrast to what is found with plants that routinely outbreed.


The main educational focus of this project was in the training of undergraduates at an undergraduate teaching institution.  Undergraduates performed the majority of the work, and to date, this project resulted in the training of a total of 11 undergraduate students, many for multiple years. These undergraduates took part in weekly research meetings, as well as a weekly journal club focused on plant evolution literature. All student researchers presented their work publicly. Seven of these students have graduated. Four students went on to graduate work in biology (One to a Ph.D. program at Washington University at St. Louis, One to a Ph.D. program at the University of Michigan, one to a Masters program at Ball State University, followed by a Ph.D. program at the University of Wyoming, and one to a Masters program at Indiana University, followed by a Ph. D. program at Purdue University). One student has gone on to medical school. Finally, one student is working on a Masters in Computer Science.
